body:
@jplu, compare_bert_results tool assumes that two ONNX models has same input data type. If --input_int32 is used, input_ids in original onnx model is int64, and optimized model has int32 inputs.

As walkaround, you can generate a model without --input_int32 for parity verification. Once the verification is done, you can add --input_int32 to generate the final model for performance test etc.

Here is example commands to run from script of master branch:
```
git clone https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime
cd onnxruntime/onnxruntime/python/tools/transformers
python -m transformers.onnx --model=bert-base-cased onnx/bert-base-cased/
python optimizer.py --input onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --output onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --model_type bert --float16
python compare_bert_results.py --baseline_model onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --optimized_model onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --input_ids input_ids --segment_ids token_type_ids --input_mask attention_mask --batch_size 1 --sequence_length 128 --samples 100
python optimizer.py --input onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --output onnx/bert-base-cased/model_int32.onnx --model_type bert --float16 --input_int32
python bert_perf_test.py --model onnx/bert-base-cased/model_int32.onnx --use_gpu -b 1 -s 128 -t 100 --opt_level 99
```

Example outputs:
```
>python optimizer.py --input onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --output onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --model_type bert --float16
               apply: Fused LayerNormalization count: 25
               apply: Fused Gelu count: 12
               apply: Fused SkipLayerNormalization count: 24
               apply: Fused Attention count: 12
         prune_graph: Graph pruned: 0 inputs, 0 outputs and 5 nodes are removed
               apply: Fused EmbedLayerNormalization(with mask) count: 1
         prune_graph: Graph pruned: 0 inputs, 0 outputs and 4 nodes are removed
         prune_graph: Graph pruned: 0 inputs, 0 outputs and 0 nodes are removed
               apply: Fused BiasGelu count: 12
               apply: Fused SkipLayerNormalization(add bias) count: 24
            optimize: opset verion: 12
  save_model_to_file: Sort graphs in topological order
  save_model_to_file: Output model to onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx
get_fused_operator_statistics: Optimized operators:{'EmbedLayerNormalization': 1, 'Attention': 12, 'Gelu': 0, 'FastGelu': 0, 'BiasGelu': 12, 'LayerNormalization': 0, 'SkipLayerNormalization': 24}
                main: The model has been fully optimized.

>python compare_bert_results.py --baseline_model onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --optimized_model onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --input_ids input_ids --segment_ids token_type_ids --input_mask attention_mask --batch_size 1 --sequence_length 128 --samples 100
WARNING: 100 out of 100 results NOT passed for thresholds (rtol=0.001, atol=0.0001).
maximum absolute difference=0.008105754852294922
maximum relative difference=1947.8863525390625
```
The threshold is for fp32 model. For fp16 model, I think the maximum absolute difference is expected (since the resolution of fp16 is around 0.001).

Thanks @tianleiwu I tried what you suggested and I get the same error with the command:
```
python -m onnxruntime.transformers.bert_perf_test --model  onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --opt_level 99 -b 1 -s 128 -t 100 --input_ids_name input_ids --input_mask_name attention_mask --segment_ids token_type_ids --use_gpu
```

```
test setting TestSetting(batch_size=1, sequence_length=128, test_cases=10, test_times=100, use_gpu=True, intra_op_num_threads=None, seed=3, verbose=False)
Generating 10 samples for batch_size=1 sequence_length=128
Process Process-2:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/process.py", line 315, in _bootstrap
    self.run()
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/multiprocessing/process.py", line 108, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/transformers/bert_perf_test.py", line 116, in run_one_test
    session = create_session(model_setting.model_path, test_setting.use_gpu, intra_op_num_threads,
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/transformers/bert_perf_test.py", line 84, in create_session
    session = onnxruntime.InferenceSession(model_path, sess_options, providers=execution_providers)
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/capi/onnxruntime_inference_collection.py", line 283, in __init__
    self._create_inference_session(providers, provider_options, disabled_optimizers)
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/capi/onnxruntime_inference_collection.py", line 310, in _create_inference_session
    sess = C.InferenceSession(session_options, self._model_path, True, self._read_config_from_model)
onnxruntime.capi.onnxruntime_pybind11_state.Fail: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 1 : FAIL : Load model from onnx/encoder/model_opt.onnx failed:/onnxruntime_src/onnxruntime/core/graph/model.cc:111 onnxruntime::Model::Model(onnx::ModelProto&&, const PathString&, const IOnnxRuntimeOpSchemaRegistryList*, const onnxruntime::logging::Logger&) Unknown model file format version.
```

The exact same error happen also when I try to just open the model:
```
import onnxruntime as ort

ort_session = ort.InferenceSession("onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx")
```

What you suggest apparently doesn't seems to work :(  any other walkaround, or is that a real bug?

@jplu, It is working in my machine.

`Unknown model file format version` is probably caused by related packages (like protobuf). You can check related packages like the following Python script:
```
import pkg_resources
installed_packages = pkg_resources.working_set
related_packages = ['flatbuffers', 'numpy', 'onnx', 'onnxconverter-common', 'onnxruntime-gpu', 'onnxruntime', 'ort-nightly-gpu', 'ort-nightly', 'protobuf', 'sympy', 'torch', 'transformers']
related_packages_list = sorted(["%s==%s" % (i.key, i.version) for i in installed_packages if i.key in related_packages])
print(related_packages_list)
```
In my machine, the output is like
```
['flatbuffers==2.0', 'numpy==1.19.5', 'onnx==1.9.0', 'onnxconverter-common==1.9.0', 'onnxruntime-gpu==1.8.1', 'protobuf==3.17.3', 'sympy==1.5', 'torch==1.9.0+cu111', 'transformers==4.9.2']
```
Also 1.8.1 need CUDA 11.0. Not sure it could work with CUDA 11.2.

BTW, you will need run optimizer.py in master branch (instead of 1.8.1) to get fully optimized model, since 1.8.1 does not 
 support the latest transformers. Also, remove --opt_level 99 in using optimizer.py, otherwise the model cannot be fully optimized.

Here is my output:
```
['flatbuffers==2.0', 'numpy==1.20.3', 'onnx==1.10.1', 'onnxconverter-common==1.8.1', 'onnxruntime-gpu==1.8.1', 'protobuf==3.17.3', 'sympy==1.8', 'torch==1.9.0+cu111', 'transformers==4.9.2']
```

> BTW, you will need run optimizer.py in master branch (instead of 1.8.1) to get fully optimized model, since 1.8.1 does not
support the latest transformers.

I can use only pypi packages for now because of some reproducible reasons.

> Also, remove --opt_level 99 in using optimizer.py, otherwise the model cannot be fully optimized.

Thanks for the hint! Good to know! Might be worth to specify this in the doc. And, by curiosity, why with this option the model cannot be fully optimized?

@jplu, I reproduced the problem with onnx 1.10.1. You can downgrade onnx to 1.9.0 to walkaround the issue. When 1.8.1 was released, onnx was at 1.9.0. I will investigate the root cause later.

--opt_level 99 will use onnxruntime to do graph optimization (written in C++). It has some extra optimizations that could change the graph, which will cause no match in attention fusion in python later.

>@jplu, I reproduced the problem with onnx 1.10.1. You can downgrade onnx to 1.9.0 to walkaround the issue. When 1.8.1 was released, onnx was at 1.9.0. I will investigate the root cause later.

Perfect, thanks a lot @tianleiwu for the walkaround. Happy to have helped to find a potential bug :)

>--opt_level 99 will use onnxruntime to do graph optimization (written in C++). It has some extra optimizations that could change the graph, which will cause no match in attention fusion in python later.

Humm I see. Do you suggest to use only `--opt_level` set to 1 or 2? Or no `--opt_level` at all?

It seems there might be another issue, even though the model can now be properly loaded it raises the following error when the inputs are in `int32`:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/jplu/anaconda3/envs/indexing/lib/python3.8/site-packages/onnxruntime/capi/onnxruntime_inference_collection.py", line 188, in run
    return self._sess.run(output_names, input_feed, run_options)
onnxruntime.capi.onnxruntime_pybind11_state.InvalidArgument: [ONNXRuntimeError] : 2 : INVALID_ARGUMENT : Unexpected input data type. Actual: (tensor(int32)) , expected: (tensor(int64))
```
The command used to get the model is still similar to what I proposed:
```
python -m onnxruntime.transformers.optimizer --input onnx/bert-base-cased/model.onnx --output onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx --disable_embed_layer_norm --model_type bert --num_heads 12 --hidden_size 768 --float16 --input_int32
```

Here also the small piece of code I used:
```
import onnxruntime as ort
from transformers import AutoTokenizer

ort_session = ort.InferenceSession("onnx/bert-base-cased/model_opt.onnx")
tokenizer = AutoTokenizer.from_pretrained("bert-base-cased")
inputs = tokenizer("Hello there!!", return_tensors="np")
inputs = {key: val.astype(np.int32) for key, val in inputs.items()}
ort_session.run(["last_hidden_state", "pooler_output"], dict(inputs))
```

@jplu, the --input_int32 is designed for model with EmbedLayerNormalization. If you disable it (--disable_embed_layer_norm), only attention mask will be converted to int32, and other two inputs are still int64. You can open the onnx file with Netron and inspect the input data types.
The thing is that even if I remove the `--disable_embed_layer_norm` I get the exact same error. Is that normal?

Apparently Netron shows that `input_ids` and `token_type_ids` are in int32 but `attention_mask` is still in int64. Here some screenshots
![Capture d’écran de 2021-08-31 10-59-45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/959590/131474303-1e145c00-ca22-4806-9e7d-d84b52338c6f.png)
![Capture d’écran de 2021-08-31 11-00-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/959590/131474319-d7f913f6-50f5-409e-957e-ae8257ea4b41.png)

issue.title: Disable some ORT graph optimizers in offline transformers optimization tool

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**: 

Disable some graph optimizers that having negative impact on transformers optimization.

Current offline transformers optimization has two passes: one pass is to use OnnxRuntime to run graph optimization, and second pass is to use fusion in Python. In the second pass, we will use symbolic shape inference. 

Currently, there are two issues caused by first pass:
(1) Some contrib ops are not supported by symbolic shape inference. That could block the optimization in the second pass.
(2) Some fusion will change the graph, which will impact fusion in Python since those graph changes might impact fusion.

**Motivation and Context**
- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

Related issue: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/8853

issue.title: Fix non deterministic of --input_int32 of transformer optimizer

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Description**:
Previous implementation of --input_int32 is non deterministic. The result will depend on optimization result. For example, when EmbedLayerNormalization is not fused, input_ids will not be changed to int32. That confuses users.

Update the logic to always change graph inputs to int32.

**Motivation and Context**
- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?
- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here.

Related issue: https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/8853
